Since $13$ is a prime, each of $a,b,c$ is invertible modulo $13$. Let $a^{-1}=x, b^{-1}=y, c^{-1}=z$ in modulo $13$. Multiplying both sides of each congruence by $(abc)^{-1}$ yields \begin{align*}
2z+x+y&\equiv 0 \pmod{13},\\
z+2x+y&\equiv 6 \pmod{13},\\
z+x+2y&\equiv 8 \pmod {13}.
\end{align*}Adding all three together gives $4(x+y+z)\equiv 14\pmod {13}\implies x+y+z\equiv 10\pmod {13}$. Subtracting this from each results in \begin{align*}
z\equiv -10\equiv 3&\pmod{13},\\
x\equiv -4\equiv 9&\pmod{13},\\
y\equiv -2\equiv 11&\pmod {13}.
\end{align*}Thus, $a+b+c\equiv x^{-1}+y^{-1}+z^{-1}\equiv 9+3+6\equiv 18\equiv \boxed{5}\pmod{13}$.

$2c\equiv a+b+22\pmod{13}$. 

Since $2^{-1}=7\pmod{13}$, we have $c\equiv 7(a+b+22)\pmod{13}$. Adding $c$ to both sides, we get $2c\equiv 7(a+b+c+22)\pmod{13}$. Then $c\equiv 7(a+b+c+22)\pmod{13} \Rightarrow c\equiv 7(a+b+c)+154\equiv 7(a+b+c)+11\pmod{13}$.

Substituting $c\equiv 7(a+b+c)+11\pmod{13}$ into $c\equiv a+b+22\pmod{13}$, we have $7(a+b+c)+11\equiv a+b+22 \Rightarrow 6(a+b+c)\equiv 11\pmod{13} \Rightarrow 2(a+b+c)\equiv 11 \pmod{13}$.

because $a$ and $c$ are non-zero, it implies a = b = c since this is modulo 13 and a,b,c < 13, the two transformations are bijective. So we take the values of a,b,c in [1,...,12] they must be equal modulo 13.
